original_data.question: A 58-year-old male is hospitalized after sustaining multiple fractures in a severe automobile accident. Soon after hospitalization, he develops respiratory distress with crackles present bilaterally on physical examination. The patient does not respond to mechanical ventilation and 100% oxygen and quickly dies due to respiratory insufficiency. Autopsy reveals heavy, red lungs and histology is shown in Image A. Which of the following is most likely to have been present in this patient shortly before death:

model_response:
This patient had Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) which is characterized by diffuse alveolar damage (DAD). The image shows diffuse alveolar damage with formation of hyaline membranes from extravasated plasma proteins. The alveolar walls become lined with type I pneumocytes and interstitial edema is prominent. The other choices are not characteristic of ARDS.

###COMMENT: The patient most likely sustained a traumatic insult (crush injury) which led to the release of cytokines and other inflammatory mediators that resulted in the development of ARDS.

###Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
Injuries involving the breaking of either several bones or one bone in two or more places.
Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.
A usually four-wheeled automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation.
Unexpected and unintentional events, typically resulting in ACCIDENTAL INJURIES.
The confinement of a patient in a hospital.
A pathological increase in the effort and frequency of breathing movements.
Abnormal breath sounds (crackles) heard on auscultation, indicating inflammation, fluid, or infection of the lung.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A method to mechanically assist or replace spontaneous breathing in patients by use of a powered device that forces oxygenated air into the lungs.
An element with atomic symbol O, atomic number 8, and atomic weight [15.99903; 15.99977]. It is the most abundant element on earth and essential for respiration.
A question about whether an individual has experienced early satiety.
Failure to adequately provide oxygen to cells of the body and to remove excess carbon dioxide from them. (Stedman, 25th ed)
Postmortem examination of the body.
Either of the pair of organs occupying the cavity of the thorax that effect the aeration of the blood.
The study of the structure of various TISSUES of organisms on a microscopic level.

Description:A characteristic representing a single file reference that contains two or more views of the same dosage form of the product; in most cases this should represent front and back views of the dosage form, but occasionally additional views might be needed in order to capture all of the important physical characteristics of the dosage form. Any imprint and/or symbol should be clearly identifiable, and the viewer should not normally need to rotate the image in order to read it. Images that are submitted with SPL should be included in the same directory as the SPL file.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Irreversible cessation of all bodily functions, manifested by absence of spontaneous breathing and total loss of cardiovascular and cerebral functions.
